doc.title: Paving the way forward
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/Investing in nature Paving the way forward Investing in natureInvesting in nature Paving the way forward Investing in na_2025-08-28

passages.text: Data limitations - whether around availability or complexity - are often blamed for cautious attitudes to investing in nature. However, solutions exist already for investors to integrate nature into the investment selection process. We outline a practical way forward for equity and credit investors.

- Nature investing strategies have evolved in recent years. On the equity side, approaches to nature fund construction have evolved towards a narrower focus on a smaller universe of solution providers with opportunities for upside. For credit investors, ESG bonds increasingly offer opportunities to invest in nature-related projects.

- Data limitations persist, but TNFD a potential solution for investors. The complexity and incompleteness of nature data is often cited as the main hurdle to nature integration. Our case study on corporate reporting suggests a nascent but growing focus on nature themes, with TNFD guidance serving to sharpen the focus on financially material disclosures.
- We identify strategies for investors to overcome these. We propose a way forward for investors to integrate nature into the investment selection process across both equities and fixed income:

- For equity investors, we see a focus on nature solution providers. Biodiversity equity funds have shifted their allocations away from sectors with low biodiversity impact scores (such as software companies) and towards names that contribute actively towards nature restoration. As such, we think sub-themes such as Water Tech, Environment Cleanup, Consulting & Compliance, Waste Management are likely to remain in focus.
- For credit, ESG bonds are becoming increasingly powerful instruments to directly finance nature projects. Green and sustainability bond issuers are increasing their
This research report has been prepared in whole or in part by equity research analysts based outside the US who are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA.
This is Special Report that is not an equity or a debt research report under U.S. FINRA Rules 2241- 2242.

This author is a debt research analyst in the Fixed Income, Currencies and Commodities Research department and is neither an equity research analyst nor subject to all of the independence and disclosure standards applicable to analysts who produce debt research reports under U.S. FINRA Rule 2242.
This author is a member of the EMEA Equity Research department who may publish equity and debt research

FOR ANALYST CERTIFICATION(S) PLEASE SEE PAGE 14. FOR IMPORTANT EQUITY RESEARCH DISCLOSURES, PLEASE SEE PAGE 14. FOR IMPORTANT FIXED INCOME RESEARCH DISCLOSURES, PLEASE SEE PAGE 15. Completed: 27- Aug- 25, 15:47 GMT Released: 28- Aug- 25, 03:00 GMT Restricted - External
allocation of proceeds to nature- related projects, but an analysis of pre- and post- issuance reporting is required to identify these opportunities.

Nature has emerged as an important theme for investors in recent years, catalysed by the signing of the Global Biodiversity Framework in 2022, which led to a convergence in expectations over the future path of government policy (Biodiversity and natural capital: mispriced and at risk). Investors have become increasingly aware of their exposure to physical and transition risks associated with holding companies that mismanage their natural capital, aided by a growing (albeit imperfect) body of nature data and risk assessment tools. Consequently, the integration of nature into financial decision- making is becoming increasingly commonplace by institutional investors, with asset managers representing c.23trn in AUM having signed the Finance for Biodiversity Pledge.

However, since the initial flurry of targets and announcements, the focus on nature has undergone a process of rationalisation and consolidation. Government policy deployment has been slower than initially anticipated, and AUM allocated to nature- themed equity funds has been flat. Meanwhile, as investors have shifted their focus from target setting to implementation, many have been confronted with the practical difficulties associated with integrating nature data into the investment selection process. Some have interpreted this as evidence of waning interest in the theme. In our view, this represents a healthy development, as investment strategies and their associated products mature to grapple with the reality at the intersection between value creation and nature conservation.

One of the most concrete ways in which this evolution has manifested has been the move away from a focus on targeting biodiversity outcomes at the portfolio level. This has been driven by a recognition that aggregated metrics such as the MSA and PDF, while convenient, come at the expense of the accuracy associated with a granular analysis of individual company exposure across a range of nature risks (for more information on the different biodiversity metrics see Biodiversity: Investing in Nature). Instead, investors have increasingly prioritised discrete topics where data availability is most complete and financial materiality is clearest. The two themes on which we have seen growing convergence have been water (Adapting to Water Risks: Tech Solutions for Mining and Chemicals) and deforestation (Deforestation, company impacts, and a palm oil case study - in 16 slides). These have particularly resonated with investors, given their critical link to operations for companies across a range of sectors, with the financial materiality of these issues cemented by an increasingly stringent regulatory architecture.

In our view, there are already well established strategies that can be robustly implemented (even by investors with limited experience in this area), despite the well documented challenges associated with nature integration.
In this note we focus on the different approaches taken by equity and fixed income investors:

- For equity investors, funds have shifted from holding companies with a low impact on nature, towards those that better align with TNFD recommendations. This has resulted in a shift away from the prevailing focus on risk mitigation, towards a framework for stock

selection characterised by an emphasis on nature solution providers with upside exposure. Our review of global bioindustry funds highlights increased holdings in financials, as insurance and reinsurance names provide exposure to earth observation solutions. Other notable priorities include investing in WaterTech, Environment Cleanup, Consulting & Compliance and also Water Management. The other notable change has been a reduction in the presence of consumer food companies, such as Danone, which coincides with a shift away from focusing on companies with a dependency on nature. Our review of burgeoning corporate TNFD and nature disclosures highlights positive momentum, with several sectors leading the way, including Metals & Mining (e.g. Teck Resources and Vale), energy (e.g. Iberdrola), water (e.g. Severn Trent), materials (e.g. Holcim) and agribusiness (e.g. Bunge).

- For fixed income investors, we still see labelled bonds as the most direct way to finance nature conservation and restoration, particularly sustainability bonds. Our analysis of the allocation reporting of these bonds shows that, on average, 4% of green bond and 1% of sustainability bond proceeds are allocated to nature-related projects. However, restricting the universe to only those bonds that have allocated to nature projects shows average allocations of 29% and 44% of proceeds, respectively1. We have seen a sharp increase in the average allocation of these bonds towards nature-related categories, with green and sustainability bonds issued in 2024 seeing average allocations of 44% and 86%, respectively.2 This suggests that corporate issuers are increasingly recognising the importance of natural capital to their operations, with ESG bonds emerging as an important instrument to finance these projects. Consequently, by carefully selecting ESG-labelled bonds issued by companies that outline an intent to finance nature projects, investors can have a direct impact on ecosystem restoration, while also participating in the upside from companies that better manage their nature-related risks.
Katherine Ogundiya Barclays, UK | Hannah Greenberg BCI, US | Siddharth Gupta Barclays, UK

Dedicated 'Biodiversity/' 'Natural Capital'- labelled equity thematic funds remain a small subset of global thematic AUM (c. \(\) 2.3bn\(vs.\) \ \(659bn\) ). We focus solely on equity funds as we do not identify any fixed income mutual funds or ETFs with the terms 'biodiversity', nature' or 'natural capital' in their names.

AUM has been relatively flat since 2024 (Figure 1), as we have seen an equal number of fund launches and closures over this period. Biodiversity fund launches reached a peak in 2023, the year that the TNFD recommendations were finalised (Figure 2). However, we have since seen the closure of prominent biodiversity equity funds in the last few years, coinciding with a decline in biodiversity fund launches. In our view, the slowdown in biodiversity fund launches can be attributed to investors waiting for more companies to make comprehensive TNFD- aligned disclosures. Performance of thematic funds has been particularly strong in recent quarters, especially for tech- related funds - Thematic Fund Review: State of Thematic Investing (2Q25) (28.07.25) - making it harder for environmental funds, which have typically not performed as well, to attract capital.
FIGURE 1. Biodiversity/Natural Capital fund AUM has hovered around \(\) 2bn\(since 2024...

Thematic AUM presented in the analysis includes sum of all share-class Total Net Assets for a given fund that existed at the end of a given month. It includes changes in valuation in underlying stocks in thematic funds \(^+\) net fund flow changes \((+ / - )\) Source: Morningstar, Barclays Research (data extracted on (19.08.25)
FIGURE 2. ...with growing fund closures potentially reflecting subdued investor sentiment
Source: Morningstar, Barclays Research (data extracted on (19.08.25)

Over the past few years we have seen different iterations of biodiversity fund formulations. Early biodiversity funds were very tech- heavy as investors prioritised holding companies with a low biodiversity footprint (as conventionally measured by the MSA or PDF score), which led to over- indexing on tech software names. Since the publication of the TNFD recommendations, holdings in biodiversity funds typically hold 'environmental solution providers'. This aligns with the TNFD focusing on key environmental issues such as water use, plastic pollution and chemical use. Per Figure 3, top holdings include Water Tech companies (e.g. Xylem),

We also see holdings in environmental solution providers that do not directly align with recommended TNFD disclosures. Notable sub- investment categories include Clean Energy (e.g. China Yangtze Power Co - hydropower generation) and Earth Observation (e.g. Munich Re). AgTech is still a popular way to play the biodiversity theme, with names such as Deere sitting within the top 20 well held stocks across global biodiversity funds. However, companies such as Trimble and Croda are less well held compared with 3Q23 holding data.

At the sector level (Figure 4), since reviewing biodiversity fund holdings in 3Q23 after we saw the first wave of fund adjustments following TNFD recommendations being finalised, allocations to Tech have remained flat. Allocations to Industrials have fallen, however we have seen an uptick in allocations to financials and utilities. The other notable change has been a reduction in the presence of consumer food companies, such as Danone, in biodiversity funds as investors prioritise solution providers. In our view, identifying environmental solution providers may be a pragmatic way to construct a biodiversity portfolio, since market analysis and growth dynamics can be calculated. This approach is also far less complicated than trying to calculate the biodiversity footprint of a company, which, in and of itself, is not a signal of outperformance with respect to stock selection.
FIGURE 3. Top holdings in biodiversity funds

Underlying StocksAccount Net Asset (%)SectorNVIDIA1.34TechnologyXylem1.18IndustrialsMicrosoft1.08TechnologySchneider Electric0.66IndustrialsChina Yangtze Power Co0.64UtilitiesVeolia Environnement0.60IndustrialsEcolab0.60Basic MaterialsApple0.56TechnologyAECOM0.53IndustrialsMunich Re0.51Financial Services
FIGURE 4. Sector allocation for biodiversity funds
Source: Morningstar, Barclays Research (data extracted on (19.08.25)

Will TNFD disclosures change investment approaches?Companies mentioning biodiversity or natural capital have increased significantly over the past five years, as the investment theme has taken hold (Figure 5). These mentions span sectors from Materials (21%), Industrials (16%), Energy (6%) and Utilities (6%) to Consumer (28%), Healthcare (4%), and Technology (5%). The question now is whether these discussions are sufficiently detailed and rich to equip investors with additional insights that can aid stock selection.
FIGURE 5. Biodiversity and natural capital are increasingly being discussed by companies
Source:Alphasense,Barclays Research

TNFD disclosures have increased, but a lack of consistency in reporting persistsData from Responsible Investor's Nature and Investors 2025 Survey highlighted several barriers to investing in nature. In our view, data availability was the most glaring gap. Over \(60\%\) of respondents stated that they had insufficient data to measure risks, impacts and dependencies of corporates. While we note that companies are talking about biodiversity more, this is often surface- level. We see more companies talking about the importance of nature; however, disclosures of a company's specific biodiversity footprint using a metric such as mean species abundance (MSA) remains very low. Given the challenges for corporates in accurately calculating metrics such as the MSA, in our view, this is unlikely to be the pre- eminent data point that investors should be relying on. Instead, we think the TNFD remains a more reliable starting point for investors seeking data on nature. Fortunately, companies are discussing the TNFD more (Figure 6), which should improve the disclosure of decision- useful information for investors with regards to nature- related risks and dependencies.
FIGURE 6. Companies discussing the TNFD have doubled since recommendations were finalised in 2023
Source:Alphasense,Barclays Research

Per our case study below, in our view, we have not reached the inflection point with sufficient TNFD corporate disclosures for investors to adapt their investment processes when investing in nature. Instead, when looking for opportunities across equities, the focus should still be identifying companies providing environment services and solutions in buoyant markets, such as within:

1. WaterTech - where PFAS regulations and industrial water demand have driven innovation (PFAS Solutions: Capturing thematic opportunities, 12.05.25 & Water Tech: Wave of Opportunity, 08.04.24).  
2. Environmental Consulting & Compliance - where regulation on environmental themes such as deforestation create opportunities (Biodiversity: Investing in Nature, 23.09.20).  
3. Waste Management - where geopolitics has put the spotlight on natural resources and the need for recycling for supply chain resilience (Critical Raw Materials: Three strategies to strengthen supply chains, 03.07.25 & Plastic Waste: Don't lose your bottle, 19.06.19).

Since the TNFD finalised its recommendations in 2023, more than 600 companies have committed to adopt the TNFD in the next couple of years, according to the Taskforce. A small subset of these companies are now making TNFD- aligned disclosures. The TNFD has encouraged this flexibility to promote broader adoption, recognising that disclosures will vary depending on sector materiality and data availability. While this can ease the burden of reporting for companies, it can also introduce hurdles for biodiversity investors. Our review of corporate TNFD disclosures highlights some potential challenges for investors:

For investors to reliably integrate TNFD data into investment decisions, critical mass must be achieved in terms of the number of companies making disclosures. For context the IFRS reports that \(82\%\) of its sample of c3.8k listed companies made disclosures against at least one of the TCFD's recommendations. TNFD disclosures across the listed space are still an exception rather than the norm. However, the breadth of sectors reporting against the TNFD is encouraging, with sectors with a high impact and dependency on biodiversity not shying away from making disclosures. For example, we see early adoption for sectors including: Metals & Mining (e.g. Teck Resources and Vale), Energy (e.g. Iberdrola), Water (e.g. Severn Trent), Materials (e.g. Holcim) and Agribusiness (e.g. Bunge). Preliminary disclosures have lagged for sectors such as Cap Goods, Consumer and Fashion. Interestingly, disclosures appear to be overweight for the Financials sector, with companies such as Schroders and Nomura reporting against the TNFD. Since the TNFD recommendations remain voluntary, there are no catalysts for mandatory adoption, although we continue to see financial institutions calling on corporates to make biodiversity disclosures.

Although more companies are discussing the TNFD, finding company disclosures can be difficult. Our analysis of early adopters reveals a lack of uniformity across where disclosures can be found and how they are formatted. Some companies have published separate TNFD or Nature reports (e.g. AstraZeneca, Seven & i Holdings and International Paper), while others have incorporated the recommendations into their sustainability or annual reports (e.g. Bunge and Holcim). The TNFD encourages integration with other sustainability- related disclosures, which can offer more holistic insights, but also lead to some variations in terminology, complicating data aggregation and comparability. Structured formats, such as tables or indices, can make it easier for investors to draw clear parallels and track progress over time.

We recognise nature disclosures remain a work in progress for many corporates. The TNFD has suggested that companies begin with the disclosures they are currently able to make and expand over time. The comply or explain basis encourages companies to provide their reasoning when they have not reported against a core global metric. British American Tobacco serves as an example of balancing early adoption with transparency on current limitations. In its 2024 TNFD report, the company chose to exclude Recommended Disclosure Governance C, stating that an analysis on indigenous peoples has not yet been conducted, while noting plans to enhance future reporting. Iberdrola is a good example of a company with extensive biodiversity reporting, which goes beyond the recommendations of the TNFD and provides lots of location- specific data. We do not expect the majority of companies to be able or willing to report with as much data as Iberdrola, but a lot of value can be extracted from even the most simple TNFD- aligned disclosures.
Jordan Isvy(1) Barclays, UK | Charlotte Edwards, CFA(1) Barclays, UK

The ESG- labelled bond market, and more specifically the use- of- proceeds bond market, has emerged as the most direct way for fixed income investors to deploy capital in support of nature conservation and restoration projects (Biodiversity in ESG- labelled bonds: Big shoes to fill). Green and sustainability bonds have historically been the most obvious instruments to achieve this, given they allocate \(100\%\) of their proceeds to either green or a combination of green and social projects, respectively. Blue bonds have also emerged as a subset of the green bond market geared towards ocean- economy projects (ICMA publishes Blue Bond guidance), although issuance has been slow to take off (Corporate ESG bond issuance: Q2 25 update). More recently, the Nature Bond designation has been introduced by ICMA as an instrument geared towards raising capital specifically for nature projects (Weekly Spotlight: ICMA introduces Nature Bonds, clarifies position on defence).

Importantly, green and sustainability bonds can finance a range of green and social projects, many of which will be unrelated to nature conservation. Therefore, to gain insight into the extent to which issuers are prioritising nature projects, we analyse trends in the inclusion of nature categories in pre- issuance frameworks across a universe of index- eligible corporate green and sustainability bonds. We define the four ICMA categories highlighted in Figure 7 as nature- related, although acknowledge that 'pollution prevention and control' projects often impact nature as a second- order effect.
FIGURE 7. We define four ICMA categories as 'nature-related'

ICMA use of proceeds categoriesEnvironmentally sustainable management of living natural resources and land useTerrestrial and aquatic biodiversitySustainable water and wastewater managementPollution prevention and controlRenewable energyClean transportationEnergy efficiencyClimate change adaptationCircular economyGreen buildings
Bolded categories are 'nature-related'. Source: ICMA, Barclays Research

We think this focus on use- of- proceeds eligibility is a useful barometer of issuer interest in the topic and of their intention to invest, and is largely complementary to the analysis of trends in proceeds allocation that we carry out subsequently. This is because nature conservation projects often involve smaller opex commitments, and therefore on average low allocation may
be more of a reflection of the relative cost of these projects rather than the extent to which natural capital is being (de)prioritised.

Figure 8 shows the share of green bonds that include at least one nature- related category as an eligible use of proceeds, weighted by amount outstanding. This shows that the share of bonds including at least an indirect category has hovered in recent years around the \(30 - 40\%\) interval. Also, there has been a marginal reduction in the share of green bonds focusing on nature since 2023, perhaps as a result of issuers coming to terms with the practical difficulty in responding to nature- related risks and dependencies following the formal publication of the TNFD recommendations.

Figure 9 repeats the exercise, but for sustainability bonds. Sustainability bond issuers are significantly more tilted towards a focus on biodiversity projects, with roughly \(80\%\) of sustainability bonds issued in 2024 containing a nature- related category as an eligible use of proceeds. We think this may be because the flexibility offered by sustainability bond structures makes them well suited to finance nature projects as part of a wider portfolio of environmental projects, with nature projects currently more of a complement than a core part of corporate sustainability strategies. This share has declined to under \(60\%\) in 2025, although, given the smaller sample of sustainability bonds issued this year, we caution against drawing strong conclusions at this point.
FIGURE 8. The share of green bonds including a nature-related category as an eligible use of proceeds has stabilised around \(30\%\) ...
FIGURE 9. ...while sustainability bond issuer have historically placed greater emphasis on nature projects
YTD as of 13 August 2025. Weighted by A/O. Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
YTD as of 13 August 2025. Weighted by A/O. Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research

Breaking down these trends at the individual nature category level, we see that sustainable water and pollution control are the most popular nature- related categories for green bond issuers (Figure 10). This is also the case for sustainability bonds (Figure 11), although biodiversity and natural resources feature more prominently. This suggests that a significant share of corporate green and sustainability bond issuers want to invest in natural capital, but do so as part of a wider sustainability strategy by including a number of eligible use of proceeds categories beyond nature.
FIGURE 10. Sustainable water and pollution control have historically been the most popular categories for green bond issuers...
FIGURE 11. ...while a greater share of sustainability bond issuers include biodiversity and natural resources as eligible use of proceeds
YTD as of 13 August 2025. Weighted by A/O. Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
YTD as of 13 August 2025. Weighted by A/O. Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research

Analysing allocation reporting can help us better understand how issuers translate the intent outlined in their pre- issuance frameworks into actual spending decisions. Looking at the same universe of index eligible green (Figure 12) and sustainability (Figure 13) bonds, we see that direct nature (abbreviated to Biodiversity, Natural Resources and Sustainable Water in the charts) and nature- adjacent categories (Pollution Control) on average account for a modest share of allocation. Indeed, for green bonds, \(4\%\) of total proceeds are allocated across these categories, while this number for sustainability bonds is closer to \(15\%\) . The higher average allocation dedicated to nature- related categories for sustainability bonds is unsurprising, given the results of our analysis of pre- issuance frameworks. Green buildings and renewable energy by some distance account for the highest share of proceed allocation, which makes sense given the significance of energy costs to companies' operating expenses.
FIGURE 12. Average allocation across project categories, green bonds
FIGURE 13. Average allocation across project categories, sustainability bonds
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
The above results are skewed by the fact many of the bonds analysed will not allocate any proceeds to nature categories. To get a fairer sense of issuer appetite to finance nature projects,

we restrict our universe to bonds with a non- zero allocation to nature categories.4 Figure 14 and Figure 15 display the results for green and sustainability bonds, respectively. We see that sustainable water is the category with the highest average allocation (10% for green bonds, 18% for sustainability bonds), which chimes with our view at the top of this report that companies are increasing their focus on water reflecting its role as a business- critical natural capital input into the production process. More widely, we see the average allocation to nature projects rise to 29% for green bonds and 44% for sustainability bonds. This discrepancy with the wider sample we analyse in Figure 12 and Figure 13 shows that, with appropriate analysis of pre- issuance frameworks, investors can have a direct impact on ecosystem restoration by carefully selecting ESG- labelled bonds issued by companies that outline an intent to finance nature projects in pre- issuance frameworks.
FIGURE 14. Average allocation across project categories, green bonds that allocate to nature categories
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
FIGURE 15. Average allocation across project categories, sustainability bonds that allocate to nature categories
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research

To assess how issuer appetite to allocate to nature projects has evolved over time, we break down the average allocation by issuance year. We present the results for green bonds in Figure 16) and sustainability bonds in Figure 17, looking at the evolution for bonds with a non- zero allocation to nature categories issued in 2022- 24. We note a sharp increase in the average allocation of towards nature- related categories, with green and sustainability bonds issued in 2024 seeing average allocations of 44% and 86% (up from 38% and 36% in 2022). For green bonds, this increase is most concentrated in the pollution control category, while there has been a non- trivial increase in the biodiversity category. Meanwhile, sustainable water and natural resources appear to be diminishing in importance, albeit from elevated base levels. For sustainability bonds (Figure 17), nature categories have risen in prominence so much so that they now make up the top three highest average allocations (natural resources, sustainable water and pollution control).

This suggests corporate issuers are increasingly recognising the importance of natural capital to their operations, with ESG- bonds emerging as an important instrument to finance these projects. Consequently, by carefully selecting ESG- labelled bonds issued by companies that outline an intent to finance nature projects, investors can have a direct impact on ecosystem
restoration, while also participating in the upside from companies that better manage their nature-related risks.
FIGURE 16. Average green bond allocation across project categories, by issuance year
FIGURE 17. Average sustainability bond allocation across project categories, by issuance year
Focuses on the subset of green bonds with an allocation to a nature category.
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
Focuses on the subset of sustainability bonds with an allocation to a nature category. Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

Any information, data, image, or other content including from a third party source contained, referred to herein or used for whatsoever purpose by Barclays or a third party ("Information"), in relation to any actual or potential 'ESG', 'sustainable' or equivalent objective, issue, factor or consideration is not intended to be relied upon for ESG or sustainability classification, regulatory regime or industry initiative purposes ("ESG Regimes"), unless otherwise stated. Nothing in these materials, including any images included therein, is intended to convey, suggest or indicate that Barclays considers or represents any product, service, person or body mentioned in these materials as meeting or qualifying for any ESG or sustainability classification, label or similar standards that may exist under ESG Regimes. Barclays has not conducted any assessment of compliance with ESG Regimes. Parties are reminded to make their own assessments for these purposes.
